executive_summary: Land developers are responsible for preparing sites prior to construction. Industry-specific activities vary between projects, but common activities include purchasing land, obtaining regulatory approval for subdivision, preparing sites and installing basic amenities such as roads and sidewalks. Only companies that earn a majority of their revenue from these prebuilding activities are considered to be part of the industry. Site preparation services offered by developers in other construction-related industries are not included in the industry. Decreases in nonresidential construction activity and increases in office rental vacancies amid the COVID-19 pandemic have negatively affected industry performance.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Residential Housing Ferried the Industry Through COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Land developers rely on a healthy residential construction market for a crucial portion of their business. Housing starts and the value of residential construction both spiked amid the pandemic, generating robust demand. Individuals migrated from cities, opting for suburban and detached single-family homes. Home builders and other contractors took advantage of near-zero interest rates to build new homes and extensions.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Costs Hinder Land Developers' Expansion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising interest rates, though, have made funding new projects expensive. Housing trends have reversed, slamming the industry with waves of volatility. Also, the price of key inputs, namely oil and steel, has piled onto rising interest rates. Oil prices have fluctuated after the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Land developers have paid significantly more to transport workers and operate heavy machinery.

Through the current period, home builders and commercial construction companies have become increasingly involved in the entire real estate development process, including purchasing land, preparing sites and selling fully constructed homes, apartments, offices and retail locations. Many contractors have opted to handle land development internally, cutting costs by reducing the number of subcontractors working on a single project.

Smaller developers, especially those without established reputations, have struggled to remain essential in construction. This trend is especially prevalent with homebuilders, especially those with access to credit. Since residential projects often have fewer moving parts compared with nonresidential and commercial construction, homebuilders can readily cut out land developers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Land Developers Adapt to Heightened Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition among key land developers will intensify through the outlook period. Although credit markets will improve and lending rates will retreat to historical levels, land development companies will remain subject to tighter lending standards, given their past performance amid the COVID-induced recession.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Developers Will Vie for Larger Projects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Developers must contend with their peers to win larger contracts to remain profitable. Larger development contracts, particularly residential projects including clubhouses, gyms and lakes, will enable land developers to negotiate input costs because they can source materials in larger quantities.

State and local governments have faced mounting pressure to allocate more funding to road, highway and airport runway construction and repair. Land developers will benefit from funding through the outlook period, creating.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Major Sporting Events Will Spur Demand for Land Developers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Major sporting events are coming to the United States; the US will host several Grand Prix events, the 2028 Los Angeles Summer Olympics and is one of three hosts to the 2026 FIFA World Cup. Public-private partnerships will fund many of these projects. This type of partnership often involves an upfront investment from the private sector followed by government spending.

industry_definition: This industry services raw land (except cemeteries) and subdivides properties into lots for subsequent sale to builders. Land subdivision precedes building activity. Servicing of land may include excavation work for
key_trends: The residential market carried the industry through the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic. Land developers were shielded from revenue loss in 2020 thanks to a boom in residential construction following urban flight caused by the pandemic.

Rising material prices in response to global tensions have hindered industry growth. The ongoing Russo-Ukrainian war has placed a strain on the supply of concrete and petroleum to Western Europe, forcing the United States to divert supplies away from domestic markets.

Rising corporate demand will buoy the industry in the coming years. US industrial concerns will have to ramp up productivity if the country wishes to retain its status as a world leader, meaning increased demand from downstream markets.

The economic decline because of the COVID-19 pandemic hindered commercial demand for land development services. A spike in housing starts caused by rapid urban flight in the early stages of the pandemic helped land developers stay afloat.

Land developers must adhere to strict building codes enacted on the state and federal levels. If codes aren't followed to the letter on each project, the structural integrity of both the project and firm is compromised.
There's no direct government assistance for land developers. Private associations are the primary source of assistance.

Demand from the nonresidential sector faltered because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The mass shutdown of the economy halted countless building projects across the country, many of which did not resume until 2022.
Site preparation for new homes is the most common market for the industry. Houses require extensive land preparation before construction can begin.

The residential market sustained the industry through the worst of the pandemic. Wealthy Americans fled urban centers with dense populations like New York City, commissioning new homes in suburban and rural areas.
Texas is the largest state for land developers. Texas is home to many private and governmental construction and infrastructure projects, meaning land development services are in high demand.

California is the second-largest state for land development. Like Texas, California is home to many private and governmental projects, requiring land development services. The proliferation of technology companies in Silicon Valley necessitates land development services.
Florida is the third-largest state for land developers. Florida's varied and volatile climate requires land developers to have extensive

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment is the largest market for land developers and includes development projects for commercial buildings, manufacturing facilities, and institutional structures. This segment also includes industry revenue from nonbuilding-related land development, including highways, streets, sidewalks, sewers, parking lots, outdoor recreational areas, sporting fields, and amusement buildings, which may be privately funded or funded by the government.
This segment includes special trade services like specialty carpentry and framing contracts, rental of construction machinery, general architectural services, and retail trade.
The residential market, which includes the development of single- and multi-family homes as well as condos and residential communities, is the second-largest market for the Land Development industry.
This segment includes specialty trade services like specialty carpentry and framing contracts.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Developing Operator-Owned Land for Nonresidential Use
products_and_services.product_description: Commercial construction, real estate investment trusts (REITs), builders, and other real estate developers purchase finished or interim-stage lots. Developers provide property grading, drainage, erosion control, and common area improvements to commercial builders.

Land developers generate a comparatively small yet significant share of industry revenue from subdivision, site preparation, and development of customer-owned land. Developers provide the normal range of construction-related services in return for real estate commissions or property management fees.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Developing Operator-Owned Land for Residential Use
products_and_services.product_description: A significant portion of land development projects include site preparation activities for the construction of single- and multifamily homes. Land developers provide a wide range of services related to construction and construction management.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from the Residential Market Boomed Amid the COVID-19 Pandemic
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The residential market, which includes the development of single- and multi-family homes as well as condos and residential communities, is the second-largest market for the Land Development industry. Home builders and other construction companies commonly purchase blue-top lots, which are properties at the interim stage of development. Residential construction boomed in the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic as those who could afford it fled dense urban areas. This carried the industry through the worst of the pandemic and made up for losses from the stagnant nonresidential construction sector.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Nonresidential and Nonbuilding Construction Activity is Beginning to Improve as Restrictions Dwindle
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment is the largest market for land developers and includes development projects for commercial buildings, manufacturing facilities, and institutional structures. This segment also includes industry revenue from nonbuilding-related land development, including highways, streets, sidewalks, sewers, parking lots, outdoor recreational areas, sporting fields, and amusement buildings, which may be privately funded or funded by the government. This market's share of revenue declined primarily because residential construction activity increased at a faster pace. The spread of COVID-19 diminished corporate profit, which resulted in decreases in demand from commercial construction. As corporate profit rises through the end of 2028, this segment will expand to reach pre-pandemic levels.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Special Trade and Other Services Include Commissions, Property Management and Several Other Smaller Industry Offerings
demand_determinants.determinant_description: These include specialty carpentry and framing contracts, rental of construction machinery, general architectural services, and retail trade. Demand for the special trade service segment has remained relatively steady over the past five years and is expected to continue performing similarly over the outlook period.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region holds the highest concentration of land developers. This is because most of the region is classified as subtropical or tropical, meaning vast differentiation in soil types and geographical conditions. Florida has the most land development outlets in the region. According to the Office of Coastal Management, Florida is 31.0% wetlands, meaning building projects require extensive, specialized site preparation from land developers.

The West is the second-largest region for land development. Because of westward expansion, much of the West (compared to the rest of the country) is still undeveloped and unoccupied, meaning a greater chance for demand for land development services.

The Southwest is the third-largest region for land development locations. This is because its vast, open and arid climate lend itself to industrial and commercial development. Texas is the single-largest state in the United States for land development thanks to a number of factors. Texas's border with Mexico, which has been the site of the controversial border wall, stretches 1,254 square miles and has required extensive land development work. Also, Texas is home to the oil industry, which also necessitates land development before extraction work can commence.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Strict planning guidelines and construction standards govern most aspects of building and construction activity in the US and the International Code Council is currently developing the International Building Code (IBC) to unify the broad range of existing codes into uniform national codes. These codes include general building codes, mechanical codes, plumbing codes, electric codes, fire codes, accessibility codes, zoning codes, state codes, local codes and ordinances.

There are multiple levels of checking for construction compliance with codes, before and during the construction. Project architects and consulting engineers check the design against current codes and standards and submit the designs to local jurisdictions to obtain the permit for construction. Governmental code officials verify compliance with codes and standards and issue a permit to enable construction to begin. And local jurisdictions periodically inspect and enforce codes during the project construction before issuing a final compliance permit.

In response to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance, various levels of regulation have been implemented in the United States and overseas to discourage public gathering, large events or crowded, unsafe work environments. Restrictions are easing in 2023 due to the widespread distribution of the COVID-19 vaccine.

basis_points.basis_description: Land developers compete with each other to secure contracts for housing and commercial building projects funded by companies and private investors.
The industry is made up of many small, regional developers. There is no major land developer with a notable market share.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is characterized by a low level of concentration, as it mainly consists of contractors that operate in specific regional markets.
With a majority of land developers operating as nonemploying organizations in local, niche markets, the industry is highly fragmented.

The largest developers currently generate less than 5.0% of industry revenue, but many developers operate on a national basis and within other industries, including residential construction, nonresidential building and property development.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Higher wages, depreciation and utilities have all contributed to the industry's lower profit.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many companies that once operated entirely within the industry began to expand into other construction activities, such as home building, as these activities offer the potential for higher revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Land developers endure high purchase costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs often fluctuate with real estate conditions, as the majority of costs are associated with land acquisitions. Land developers are required to purchase materials used during excavations, development and landscaping, including ready-mixed concrete, stone, structural steel, concrete panels, structural timber, metal cladding and other materials used during excavations and landscaping.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Prospective developers can cut costs early on by hiring subcontractors instead of a regular labor force.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Still, land development requires significant human labor, be it through volume or hours worked

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatility in line with related industries
volatility_points.volatility_description: In line with other industries related to building and construction, the industry has exhibited a medium degree of volatility. Revenue volatility is closely linked to downstream demand and fluctuations in input material prices. Recently, escalating international tensions have placed a strain on the supply of concrete, gasoline and lumber to the United States and its allies, driving up prices for the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Demand from the residential market eased volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the past five years, a steadily improving economy and a resurgence in the housing market have buoyed an expansion in home building and commercial construction. Although the free fall in demand for land development services has subsided because of increased construction activity, the industry has contracted over the period due to the diminished role of specialized land developers.

FAQs.question: Are you solely focused on new work, or do you participate in remodeling activities?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry are focused on new work, as land that is developed must not have any buildings on it already.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets? Can you easily switch between these markets?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this can switch between these markets, depending on the size of their operations. Most of the companies work in residential and nonresidential construction markets.

FAQs.question: How does your company compete for contracts with larger businesses? Do you ever find you lack the capacity to deliver on more-lucrative projects?
FAQs.answer: Most large operators in the industry compete on the basis of quality, especially for lucrative contracts with large projects. These operators typically do not lack the capacity to deliver on more-lucrative projects.

FAQs.question: What is the size of your staff? How does that compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Most operators are nonemployers or operators with few employees, while bigger operators focus on larger contracts with commercial or large residential property developers.

FAQs.question: Investment in new technology is usually fairly low among builders and contractors. How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Depreciation is very low in this industry, accounting for less than 3.4% of industry revenue annually.

FAQs.question: Have productivity issues ever kept you from winning lucrative contracts over larger competitors?
FAQs.answer: Lucrative contracts are typically awarded to larger operators that have the resources to complete a quality job in a specific time for the right price.

FAQs.question: Do you work with local or national trade associations to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: There are no trade associations that advance company interests.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have not significantly impacted company profitability.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: IBISWorld expects profit margins to be relatively similar across the industry, accounting for 17.0% of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients are return customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have a varied amount of return customers. For larger projects, a company may have a return customer since they specialize in that field.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? How do you keep wages competitive?
FAQs.answer: Given the high-risk nature of property development, successful land developers seek to minimize risk by employing suitably qualified or experienced marketing and financial management personnel. Giving more incentives such as health benefits, employee reimbursement and promotions attracts qualified staff and retains them. To keep wages competitive, more contracts have to be acquired or decrease profit margin to retain staff.

FAQs.question: Do you closely monitor available adjacent land?
FAQs.answer: Land developers must be able to expand successfully developed projects by accessing adjacent land.

FAQs.question: What methods do you take to find new investment opportunities?
FAQs.answer: The successful investment into new land for developing and subdivision requires an astute choice of location and scale of development.

FAQs.question: Has your company encountered difficulties obtaining credit in the current lending market?
FAQs.answer: The yield on the 10-year Treasury note directly affects interest rates. If the companies track record of interest payments and credit score is good, there is not difficulty in obtaining credit from the market.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor and respond to revenue and profit trends in nonresidential construction?
FAQs.answer: The nonresidential construction market generates a significant share of industry revenue. If demand from nonresidential construction sector increases, demand for new construction also increases, which helps land developers attract contractors either by selling the land or partnering with them.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from servicing the commercial property market?
FAQs.answer: More than 12.0% of revenue is derived from commercial property market.
